subtopics.title: Using 'be' verbs (is, am, are, was, were)

sections.text: When the sentence has 'is', 'am', 'are', 'was', or 'were', we put these words at the start of the sentence to make a question. These questions can be answered with 'Yes' or 'No'.

examples.label: Statement
examples.value: The buffalo is in the pond.

examples.label: Question
examples.value: Is the buffalo in the pond?

examples.label: Statement
examples.value: My father was working in the field.

examples.label: Question
examples.value: Was my father working in the field?

examples.label: Statement
examples.value: The crops are ready for harvest.

examples.label: Question
examples.value: Are the crops ready for harvest?

examples.label: Statement
examples.value: The well was full of water.

examples.label: Question
examples.value: Was the well full of water?

usage_examples: Am I late for the bus?
Was the teacher in the class?
Were your friends at the market?
Are the cows in the shed?

sections.text: When a sentence does not have 'is', 'am', 'are', 'was', 'were', or a helping verb like 'can' or 'will', we use 'do', 'does', or 'did' to make a question. We use 'do' for 'I', 'you', 'we', 'they'. We use 'does' for 'he', 'she', 'it'. We use 'did' for all subjects in the past.

examples.label: Question
examples.value: Does he work in the factory?

examples.label: Question
examples.value: Did the villagers help each other?

examples.label: Question
examples.value: Do birds fly in the sky?

examples.label: Question
examples.value: Did the boy draw a picture?

examples.label: Question
examples.value: Does my sister clean the house?

examples.label: Question
examples.value: Did I tell you the truth?

usage_examples: Does your father go to the field early?
Do they visit the temple every week?
Do you know the way to the river?

subtopics.title: Using Modal Verbs (can, will, should, must)

sections.text: Modal verbs like 'can', 'will', 'should', 'must' also go to the start of the sentence to form a question. These also ask for a 'Yes' or 'No' answer.

examples.label: Statement
examples.value: You must listen to your parents.

examples.label: Question
examples.value: Must you listen to your parents?

examples.label: Statement
examples.value: The boy can climb the tree.

examples.label: Question
examples.value: Can the boy climb the tree?

examples.label: Statement
examples.value: The bus will leave at 5 PM.

examples.label: Question
examples.value: Will the bus leave at 5 PM?

usage_examples: Must we go to the market now?

sections.text: 'What' is used to ask about things, ideas, or actions.

examples.label: Answer
examples.value: There are vegetables in the basket.

examples.label: Question
examples.value: What did the old woman say?

examples.label: Answer
examples.value: It is the sound of thunder.

examples.label: Answer
examples.value: I will go to the city.

usage_examples: What is the name of your village?

sections.text: 'Where' is used to ask about places or locations.

examples.label: Answer
examples.value: I am going to the market.

examples.label: Answer
examples.value: The well is near the big tree.

examples.label: Question
examples.value: Where did you put the tools?

examples.label: Answer
examples.value: I put the tools in the shed.

examples.label: Answer
examples.value: The school is behind the temple.

examples.label: Answer
examples.value: The animals went to the forest.

examples.label: Answer
examples.value: The river flows near our village.

examples.label: Answer
examples.value: Your books are on the table.

examples.label: Question
examples.value: Where did you find the lost goat?

examples.label: Answer
examples.value: I found the lost goat near the bushes.

examples.label: Question
examples.value: Where will you plant this tree?

examples.label: Answer
examples.value: I will plant it by the river.

examples.label: Answer
examples.value: It was held in the village square.

usage_examples: Where can I find fresh vegetables?

sections.text: 'When' is used to ask about time.

examples.label: Answer
examples.value: The festival will begin next month.

examples.label: Question
examples.value: When do you usually eat dinner?

examples.label: Answer
examples.value: I usually eat dinner at 7 PM.

examples.label: Question
examples.value: When did you plant these seeds?

examples.label: Answer
examples.value: The market opens in the morning.

examples.label: Answer
examples.value: The moon will rise at night.

examples.label: Question
examples.value: When did you last visit your relatives?

examples.label: Question
examples.value: When are you harvesting the crops?

examples.label: Answer
examples.value: We are harvesting them next week.

examples.label: Question
examples.value: When did the rain finally stop?

usage_examples: When did you finish your work?
When do you go to the river?

sections.text: 'Who' is used to ask about people.

examples.label: Answer
examples.value: The new teacher will teach us.

examples.label: Question
examples.value: Who is the head of your family?

examples.label: Question
examples.value: Who is coming to the gathering?

usage_examples: Who will go to the fair?

sections.text: 'Why' is used to ask for reasons.

examples.label: Question
examples.value: Why did the cow run away?

examples.label: Answer
examples.value: Because it heard a loud noise.

examples.label: Question
examples.value: Why did the well dry up?

examples.label: Question
examples.value: Why did you choose this path?

usage_examples: Why is the village quiet today?
Why do you like this place?

sections.text: 'How' is used to ask about the way something happens, condition, or amount.

examples.label: Question
examples.value: How do you go to school?

examples.label: Question
examples.value: How much milk do you need?

examples.label: Answer
examples.value: I need one liter of milk.

examples.label: Question
examples.value: How was your day at the farm?

examples.label: Question
examples.value: How can we help the village?

usage_examples: How did the farmer plough the field?
How many people live in your house?
How often do you visit the city?

sections.text: 'Which' is used when asking about a choice from a group of items.

examples.label: Question
examples.value: Which fruit do you like, mango or apple?

examples.label: Question
examples.value: Which path leads to the river?

examples.label: Question
examples.value: Which color pot do you need?

examples.label: Question
examples.value: Which animal is faster, a rabbit or a tortoise?

examples.label: Answer
examples.value: The one with the flowers is mine.

examples.label: Question
examples.value: Which season do you like best?

examples.label: Answer
examples.value: I like the rainy season best.

examples.label: Question
examples.value: Which farmer has the biggest field?

examples.label: Answer
examples.value: Ramu Kaka has the biggest field.

examples.label: Question
examples.value: Which of these stories do you want to hear?

examples.label: Answer
examples.value: I want to hear the one about the clever fox.

usage_examples: Which bus goes to the city?
Which pen is better, this one or that one?
Which river is longer, Ganga or Yamuna?

subtopics.title: Negatives with 'be' verbs (is, am, are, was, were)

sections.text: To make a sentence negative when it has 'is', 'am', 'are', 'was', or 'were', we simply add 'not' after these words.
When a sentence does not have 'be' verbs or modal verbs, we use 'do not' (don't), 'does not' (doesn't), or 'did not' (didn't) to make it negative. The main verb stays in its simple form.

examples.label: Negative
examples.value: We do not walk to school.

examples.label: Negative
examples.value: He does not work in the factory.

examples.label: Negative
examples.value: The cow does not give milk.

examples.label: Negative
examples.value: The villagers did not help each other.

examples.label: Negative
examples.value: Birds do not fly at night.

examples.label: Negative
examples.value: The sun does not shine at night.

examples.label: Negative
examples.value: The boy did not draw a picture.

examples.label: Negative
examples.value: You do not understand this lesson.

examples.label: Negative
examples.value: My sister does not like to sing.

examples.label: Negative
examples.value: I do not believe his story.

examples.label: Negative
examples.value: The fire did not burn brightly.

usage_examples: They did not come to the gathering.
We do not have enough water.
He does not know the answer.
My parents do not allow it.

subtopics.title: Negatives with Modal Verbs (can, will, should, must)

sections.text: For sentences with modal verbs, we add 'not' after the modal verb to make them negative.

examples.label: Statement
examples.value: He can lift the heavy stone.

examples.label: Negative
examples.value: He cannot lift the heavy stone.

examples.label: Negative
examples.value: The train will not be late.

examples.label: Negative
examples.value: You must not forget this lesson.

sections.text: When 'have', 'has', 'had' are used as main verbs (meaning 'possess' or 'own'), we use 'do not have', 'does not have', or 'did not have' to make them negative.

examples.label: Negative
examples.value: I do not have a book.

examples.label: Negative
examples.value: He does not have a cow.

examples.label: Negative
examples.value: We do not have much work.

examples.label: Negative
examples.value: She does not have a bicycle.

examples.label: Statement
examples.value: The school has a big ground.

examples.label: Negative
examples.value: The school does not have a big ground.

examples.label: Statement
examples.value: My brother had a new shirt.

examples.label: Negative
examples.value: My brother did not have a new shirt.

examples.label: Negative
examples.value: The house does not have electricity.

examples.label: Negative
examples.value: Farmers do not have strong hands.

examples.label: Negative
examples.value: The village did not have peace.

examples.label: Negative
examples.value: You do not have a good idea.

examples.label: Negative
examples.value: The dog does not have a bone.

usage_examples: I do not have a pen.
They did not have water yesterday.
She does not have any problems.
Our village does not have a hospital.
We do not have a holiday tomorrow.

sections.text: A question tag is a short question at the end of a statement. We use it to check if something is true or to ask someone to agree with us. If the main statement is positive, the tag is negative. If the main statement is negative, the tag is positive. We use a comma before the tag.

examples.label: Positive Statement, Negative Tag
examples.value: He is a farmer, isn't he?

examples.label: Negative Statement, Positive Tag
examples.value: She is not here, is she?

examples.label: Negative Statement, Positive Tag
examples.value: They did not come, did they?

examples.label: Positive Statement, Negative Tag
examples.value: It is hot today, isn't it?

examples.label: Positive Statement, Negative Tag
examples.value: You like to play, don't you?

examples.label: Positive Statement, Negative Tag
examples.value: The sun rises in the east, doesn't it?

examples.label: Positive Statement, Negative Tag
examples.value: The children are playing, aren't they?

examples.label: Positive Statement, Negative Tag
examples.value: You should help your parents, shouldn't you?

examples.label: Positive Statement, Negative Tag
examples.value: He will come to the village fair, won't he?

examples.label: Negative Statement, Positive Tag
examples.value: We are not going to the city, are we?

examples.label: Negative Statement, Positive Tag
examples.value: The buffalo wasn't in the pond, was it?

examples.label: Negative Statement, Positive Tag
examples.value: You don't eat meat, do you?

examples.label: Negative Statement, Positive Tag
examples.value: She doesn't like spicy food, does she?

examples.label: Negative Statement, Positive Tag
examples.value: They haven't finished the work, have they?

examples.label: Negative Statement, Positive Tag
examples.value: It won't rain today, will it?

examples.label: Positive Statement, Negative Tag
examples.value: He passed the test, didn't he?

examples.label: Negative Statement, Positive Tag
examples.value: You couldn't find it, could you?

usage_examples: It's a beautiful day, isn't it?
The food was delicious, wasn't it?
He doesn't have a brother, does he?

sections.text: When someone asks a question tag, you answer with 'Yes' or 'No', followed by the helping verb from the tag and the correct pronoun. The answer should match the truth, not the tag's positive or negative form.

examples.label: Question Tag
examples.value: He is a farmer, isn't he?

examples.label: Question Tag
examples.value: The children are playing, aren't they?

examples.label: Question Tag
examples.value: The well is not dry, is it?

examples.label: Question Tag
examples.value: Your brother will help, won't he?

examples.label: Question Tag
examples.value: He has a tractor, doesn't he?

usage_examples: It's cold, isn't it? Yes, it is.
You don't understand, do you? No, I don't.
She works hard, doesn't she? Yes, she does.
They weren't late, were they? No, they weren't.
We should leave now, shouldn't we? Yes, we should.
He won't tell anyone, will he? No, he won't.
